Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Renewable Energy
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL PART: Each summer the REU Site will invite nine undergraduate students and one secondary school teacher to Colorado School of Mines (CSM) to perform cutting-edge research in renewable energy. These highly interdisciplinary studies are open to all undergraduate students majoring in engineering, materials science, chemistry, physics, mathematics, and computer science. The secondary school teacher will be active in math, science, or preparatory engineering classes. Students will participate in a 10-week effort, while the teacher will be immersed in a synchronous 5-week program that blends a research experience with a curriculum development expectation. All participants will work directly with CSM faculty mentors and scientific staff from the nearby National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) and the on-campus Renewable Energy Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (REMRSEC). As the nation's primary laboratory for renewable energy and energy efficiency research and development, NREL partners with REMRSEC to continuously develop undergraduate students' skills, knowledge, and interests in renewable energy with the purpose of creating a pipeline that supports its future research strands and employment needs.

TECHNICAL PART: The project will provide CSM graduate students the opportunity to assist faculty mentors in the design and delivery of research projects suitable for undergraduate students and secondary school teachers. Projects include modeling electrical charge transport in quantum dot structures, characterizing the performance of novel fuel cells, improving wind turbine designs, investigating hydrogen gas storage techniques, developing low cost but highly efficient thin film solar cells, and synthesizing lithium ion batteries. In addition to their research pursuits, participants will be immersed in experiential education activities that include field trips, hands-on laboratory tours, professional development sessions, and weekly technical seminars with renewable energy themes. At the end of the summer, all participants will share their results at a formal scientific Poster Session with participants from neighboring research programs. Students who produce significant research results will be encouraged to publish their work in scientific journals and/or present their studies at scientific conferences. The teacher will share his or her results with district teachers at the Colorado Science Conference for Professional Development held each November in downtown Denver or at a National Science Teachers Association conference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:  The Renewable Energy REU Site at Colorado School of Mines fully supported 10 participants (9 undergraduate students and 1 secondary school science teacher) in materials-related renewable energy research endeavors.  Joining these individuals were 32 other REU participants that were engaged in research in other STEM areas at Mines during the 2017 summer.  A no-cost extension allowed the REU to support 6 additional students during the 2018 summer.  Through our series of Professional Development Sessions and Weekly Technical Seminars, as well as special events that included field trips, lab tours, science education outreach endeavors, webinars, and workshops, all 42 participants increased their awareness of the multidisciplinary aspects of scientific research in general, and renewable energy research in particular.  Many demonstrated a genuine interest in pursuing advanced degrees in STEM fields that have strong connections to renewable energy, environmental science, or climate change.  Research, and the research process, is no longer a nebulous mystery, but a necessary educational step if one wishes to help tackle many of the challenging technical problems our world faces.

 

Participants worked with researchers comprised of faculty mentors and scientific staff from Mines, the Colorado Energy Research Institute (CERI), the Colorado Fuel Cell Center (CFCC), the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL), and Mines’ Renewable Energy Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (REMRSEC).  Mentors all had previous, demonstrated records of introducing talented undergraduate students and secondary school science teachers to the excitement of discovery through participation on vibrant research teams.  Projects were tailored to provide participants and their peer mentors with authentic research experiences, as well as training and independence in a research environment.

 

Professional Development Sessions addressed laboratory safety, hands-on fire extinguisher training, problem-solving in social contexts, what it takes to become an expert in a field, applying to graduate school, ethics in science and engineering, the Imposter Syndrome, evidence-based explanations, and moral psychology.  Weekly Technical Seminars covered critical materials research, mining engineering, computational guidance in materials discovery, thermal stability of battery electrolytes, photovoltaics as part of a renewable energy economy, using 3-D printing techniques to produce better materials, and cybersecurity strategies.  A joint networking program for Front Range REU students and summer interns brought together groups of undergraduate STEM majors in a program that authenticated the value of their current engineering and science pursuits; nurtured their near-term transitions into careers, graduate studies, and professional organizations; and outlined ethical standards and transferable skills that are needed to tackle the challenges facing global societies.

 

Broader Impacts:  The 2017 Renewable Energy REU at Colorado School of Mines strove for gender equity and diversity as we judiciously selected students from underrepresented groups and from institutions where research was limited.  A networking program for Front Range REU students and summer interns brought together groups of undergraduate STEM majors from 9 unique groups: 

1) Advancing Polymer Materials by Integrating Chemistry and Chemical Engineering REU at Mines

2) Ball Aerospace & Technologies Corporation Summer Interns in Boulder, CO

3) Bridge Opportunities for Transfer Student Success (BOTS) program at Mines

4) Lockheed Martin Space Systems Company in Littleton, CO

5) National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) REU in Boulder, CO

6) Red Rocks Community College STEM Scholars Summer Research Program in Lakewood, CO

7) Re-Inventing the Nation's Urban Water Infrastructure (ReNUWIt) REU at Mines, New Mexico State University, Stanford University, and University of California Berkeley

8) Renewable Energy REU at Colorado School of Mines

9) Undergraduate Research Interns at National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) in Golden, CO
